author: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Jason Horowitz
title: New ‘Variant of Concern’ Fuels Global Fear of Another Virus Surge
description: Scientists do not yet know how dangerous the new Omicron variant is, but its many mutations set off alarms, lowering hopes of putting the pandemic in the past.
content: The world reacted with alarm on Friday to the highly mutated new coronavirus variant discovered in southern Africa, as the United States, the European Union and nations across the globe imposed new travel restrictions, financial markets swooned and visions of finally emerging from the pandemic started to dim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Schaff and Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Bay: Beyond the Prison
description: With 6,000 residents and the feel of a college campus, the U.S. Navy base has some of the trappings of small-town America, and some of a police state.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Mention this place, and people tend to think of caged men wearing orange uniforms and on their knees, the image of opening day at the wartime prison four months after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Robberies are becoming an increasing concern for retailers.
description: About 69 percent of stores said they have seen an increase in organized theft in the past year.
content: Retailers are expressing more concerns about robberies this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Katherine Clemmons
title: Pushed by Players, the N.F.L. Works to Embrace Mental Health
description: N.F.L. teams have standardized support for mental wellness as their players fight social stigmas and the league’s “just play through it” ethos.
content: Defensive lineman Solomon Thomas remembers sitting at lunch one day during his rookie season in San Francisco in 2016 and pointing out the 49ers’ team therapist at an adjacent table. “Oh no, we can’t go over there,” he said a teammate told him. “Otherwise, we look like we’re crazy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Markets Tumble as New Coronavirus Variant Brings Travel Restrictions
description: Stocks and oil futures slumped, while investors sought safety in government bonds.
content: Stocks around the world fell on Friday and oil prices plunged, after evidence of a new coronavirus variant in South Africa prompted another round of travel restrictions and reignited concerns about the economic toll imposed by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: The Art of Politics
description: Kate Hawkins opens our solving weekend and asks us to stay in touch.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Kate Hawkins returns with her eighth New York Times crossword puzzle, and she has clearly missed us. Just take a look at 7D.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A Tree That Was Once the Suburban Ideal Has Morphed Into an Unstoppable Villain
description: The Bradford pear, hugely popular when suburbs were developed, contributed to an invasion of trees conquering nearly anywhere it lands. South Carolina is stepping up its fight against it.
content: CLEMSON, S.C. — In the distance, beside a brick house in a tidy subdivision, the trees rose above a wooden fence, showing off all that had made the Bradford pear so alluring: They were towering and robust and, in the early spring, had white flowers that turned their limbs into perfect clouds of cotton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige Darrah
title: How a Book- Pickle- and Tchotchke-Seller Spends Sundays
description: When she’s not at her whimsical secondhand shop, Leigh Altshuler plays board games and visits neighbors.
content: The telephone shaped like a Cabbage Patch doll in the front window will set you back $295. Or at least it would if the seller was willing to part with it. Passers-by ask about it constantly. Instead, they are welcome to choose among memoirs by 1990s sitcom stars, yellowing Chopin sheet music, and illustrated books on dog grooming. And pickles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ann Patchett on ‘These Precious Days’
description: Patchett talks about her new essay collection, and Corey Brettschneider discusses a series of books about liberty.
content: The novelist Ann Patchett’s latest book, “These Precious Days,” is a collection of essays. It’s anchored by the long title piece, which originally appeared in Harper’s Magazine, about her intimate friendship with a woman who moved to Nashville for cancer treatment just as the coronavirus pandemic started. On the podcast this week, Patchett, who is also a Nashville bookstore owner, discusses the collection and talks about how writing essays fits into her creative life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Shribman
title: In Canada, the Premier of Quebec Worries About the State of Hockey
description: With the Montreal Canadiens in a losing funk, François Legault has expressed concern about the declining number of Quebec-born pros and vowed to get to the bottom of it.
content: MONTREAL — Of all the shortages that have emerged across the globe this year and attracted high-level political attention, the most astonishing may be this: the scarcity of Quebecers in professional hockey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Europe’s Theaters Go Back to the Future With Covid Restrictions
description: Strict controls on playhouses and music venues are returning as the continent deals with a new coronavirus wave.
content: For months, Europe’s opera, music and theater fans have been flocking to packed venues as if the coronavirus pandemic was fading from view. Now that feeling of freedom is receding for many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Pierson and Emma Pierson
title: Genetic Risks for Cancer Should Not Mean Financial Hardship
description: People with markers for cancer often need more screenings. But health insurers are not required to fully cover them.
content: Tens of millions of Americans have received genetic tests illuminating their risk of disease, and a majority of adults in the United States say they would be interested in getting tested. When we each turned 20, we sought genetic testing to learn whether we had inherited our mother’s BRCA mutation, which significantly increases the risk of breast, ovarian and other cancers. We each had a 50 percent chance of inheriting it, but our fates diverged: One of us, Emma, has the mutation, and the other, Leah, does not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Watching Team
title: Here Are 5 Family-Friendly Things to Stream This Weekend
description: Hosting relatives for the holiday weekend? Here are some great films and series that will appeal to all ages.
content: The holiday weekend is here! We want to help by taking one thing off your plate. We’ve gone through Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime Video and Disney+ to find the best titles that are suitable for the entire family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Merck says its antiviral pill is less effective in a final analysis.
description: The drug, molnupiravir, reduced the risk of hospitalization and death in high-risk Covid patients by 30 percent. An earlier analysis had found a 50 percent reduction.
content: The pharmaceutical company Merck said on Friday that in a final analysis of a clinical trial, its antiviral pill reduced the risk of hospitalization and death among high-risk Covid patients by 30 percent, down from an earlier estimate of 50 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Abend
title: A Refugee’s Harrowing Story, Finally Told Through Animation
description: Jonas Poher Rasmussen’s childhood friend kept his flight from Afghanistan secret for 20 years. Now, Rasmussen has told his story through the award-winning film “Flee.”
content: COPENHAGEN — Midway through Jonas Poher Rasmussen’s latest documentary, a decrepit boat crowded with Afghans fleeing violence crosses paths with a gleaming Norwegian cruise ship somewhere in the Baltic Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Foo Fighters Perform Under a Blue Whale
description: And New York Public Radio honors Radiolab at its dinner gala.
content: The American Museum of Natural History raised about $3 million at its annual fall gala on Nov. 18, with 450 guests dining under the big blue whale in the Hall of Ocean Life. As usual, there was a large contingent of “Saturday Night Live” cast members. (Lorne Michaels, the show’s longtime producer, sits on the museum’s board.) And New York Public Radio held its annual gala on Nov. 16 at the Plaza Hotel; the Radiolab podcast, now in its 20th year, was honored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: She Fell for the Art, Then for the Artist
description: A neighbor introduced Becky Headen to Tony Hernandez’s artwork in 2001. Twelve years later, they had a first date.
content: Rebekah Headen fell in love with Tony Hernandez years before she actually met him. Not only that, it was love at first sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: New to ‘It’s Always Sunny’? Watch These 5 Episodes (at Your Own Risk)
description: The sitcom, about to become American TV’s longest-running live-action comedy, isn’t everyone’s kind of humor. These episodes capture the show’s brand of boundary-pushing satire.
content: “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” is one of the most successful comedies in TV history, but it isn’t for everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: ‘Afghan Girl’ From 1985 National Geographic Cover Takes Refuge in Italy
description: Sharbat Gula, whose haunting portrait was featured by the magazine more than three decades ago, was evacuated to Rome after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.
content: Sharbat Gula, who became an international symbol of war-torn Afghanistan after her portrait at a refugee camp was published on the cover of National Geographic magazine in 1985, was evacuated to Rome after her country fell to the Taliban, the Italian government said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Stephen Sondheim, Titan of the American Musical, Is Dead at 91
description: He was the theater’s most revered and influential composer-lyricist of the last half of the 20th century and the driving force behind some of Broadway’s most beloved and celebrated shows.
content: Stephen Sondheim, one of Broadway history’s songwriting titans, whose music and lyrics raised and reset the artistic standard for the American stage musical, died early Friday at his home in Roxbury, Conn. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: It’s Always Sunny With Rob McElhenney
description: The FXX series “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” is about to become the longest-running live-action sitcom in U.S. history. Its energetic star and creator wants to know what’s next.
content: LOS ANGELES — The past year in California has been the driest in a century. But on a recent mid-November afternoon, California was starting to look a lot like … Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Irina Aleksander
title: In Good Spirits
description: Carissa Schumacher channels the dead for her A-list celebrity clients.But most days, she’s in the forest.
content: Last Saturday night, a group gathered at the Flamingo Estate in the Eagle Rock neighborhood of Los Angeles to meet the spiritual adviser Carissa Schumacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Steven Lee Myers
title: In I.O.C.’s ‘Quiet Diplomacy,’ Critics See Whitewash of China’s Actions
description: The handling of the Peng Shuai case raised new questions about the I.O.C.’s relationship with China. One Olympic official called its actions ‘discreet.’ Critics called it collaboration.
content: The International Olympic Committee was under siege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Léontine Gallois
title: Protesters in Martinique fire at police officers and journalists.
description: Protests against the French island’s coronavirus protocols, requiring a health pass to enter most public venues, have been exacerbated by frustrations and anger over economic inequality with the mainland.
content: PARIS — Protesters fired live ammunition at journalists and the police on Thursday night on the French Caribbean island of Martinique, injuring dozens of officers, one of them seriously, a spokesman for the French government said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Why Gen Z Is Flocking to New York’s Old-School Hotels and Bars
description: Bemelmans Bar now has bouncers. And at the Rainbow Room, a post-punk after party.
content: It was a scene that would have shocked Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, a longtime patron of the Carlyle: a security team had been posted inside the hotel’s corridor to manage the crowds lining up for its elegant bar, Bemelmans. It was early Friday afternoon; way before cocktail hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Inside a Terrarium, It’s Always Gardening Season
description: As winter closes in, there’s at least one place where plants will still grow: a terrarium. Here’s how to get started on yours.
content: During the months when you can’t be outside working in the garden, what could be better than a miniature landscape that sits in your living room?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an amnesiac romance and acts of sentient killer robot rampage.
content: Rent or buy from most major platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: After Murders ‘Doubled Overnight,’ the N.Y.P.D. Is Solving Fewer Cases
description: In the Bronx, where the percentage of murders solved by the police has plunged, one family is waiting impatiently for a day that may not come.
content: Maria Rosario has an unopened bottle of champagne ready for the day the police finally catch the man who killed her nephew, JayQuan Lewis. Mr. Lewis’s best friend already has an outfit picked out. And Marisol Sanchez, Mr. Lewis’s mother, says she will throw a party outside the local police station: She has a bakery on standby, to make the cake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikkya Hargrove
title: A Father-in-Law’s Embrace, Not a Moment Too Soon
description: She wasn’t who her in-laws expected their daughter to marry. But on the eve of her wedding, her father-in-law made it clear she was family.
content: We stood in the same living room my fiancée sat in as a child watching Saturday morning cartoons. It was the night before our wedding, and in front of our families, friends and her parents’ friends at the rehearsal dinner, her father pulled out a tiny, white piece of paper from his shirt pocket. The smile on his face told me he was both nervous and uncertain about the impending response from the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: After ‘Mist,’ They Saw Things Differently
description: An evening at Mist Harlem, a former restaurant and bar, propelled Walter Smith-Randolph and LeAnne Armstead’s 12-year friendship into something more.
content: Walter Smith-Randolph said he was interested in LeAnne Armstead from the moment he met her at a 2005 barbecue hosted by Villanova University’s Black Cultural Society.
source.name: The New York Times

title: See photos from Black Friday around the United States and Europe.
description: Gaming consoles and TVs were among the most popular items at the beginning of the holiday shopping season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
title: Jakucho Setouchi, 99, Dies; Buddhist Priest Wrote of Sex and Love
description: Her more than 400 novels often drew on her own romantic affairs, and her translation of an 11th-century romantic Japanese classic sold millions of copies.
content: TOKYO — Jakucho Setouchi, a Buddhist priest and feminist author who wrote frankly about sex, entertained audiences with her insouciant wit and rendered one of Japan’s greatest classic works into a readable best seller, died on Nov. 9 in Kyoto, Japan. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong
title: Back to full capacity and on the hunt for Legos in New Jersey.
description: A father of three got some Christmas shopping done and the Garden State Plaza expected a busy day.
content: PARAMUS, N.J. — Karl Tangara, a father of three, hurried into the Garden State Plaza mall’s east entry at 6:45 a.m. on Black Friday, pulled a handcart with three blue IKEA bags folded beneath a strap and approached Jay Daly, the mall’s senior general manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Coffee or Chai? At 2 Kolkata Cafes, ‘Adda’ Is What’s Really on the Menu
description: Unrestricted talk, or “adda,” is the main draw at two storied cafes that are at once museums to the city’s intellectual history — and places for debate.
content: KOLKATA, India — At one of the cafes, to ask for chai is to invite a gaze of withering contempt from the turbaned waiter, as if blasphemy has been committed: It’s called the Indian Coffee House, stupid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: Virus Variant, Stephen Sondheim, Leftovers: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Eat leftovers, take stock.
content: Welcome. Let’s talk about leftovers. It’s the day after Thanksgiving, and while I have been looking forward to spending the day with people I haven’t seen for two years, I was perhaps equally anticipating Leftovers Friday, which is the first day, really, of Leftovers Weekend. I hope you’ve availed yourself of a sandwich with all the fixings by the time you read this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: The Penthouse That Keeps Breaking Records in SoHo
description: The triplex on Broome Street sold for $49 million, which was the most expensive closing in New York City in November.
content: For the second time in just over a year, a sprawling triplex on Broome Street set a record for the highest price paid for a single residence in SoHo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yasmine Mosimann and Valerie Hopkins
title: Iraqis Return From Belarus, but Some Say They Will Try Again to Reach the E.U.
description: “If I find a better and safe route, I will definitely try again,” said one of the more than 600 Iraqi migrants who came home on the government’s latest evacuation flights.
content: ERBIL, Iraq — Iraq repatriated a second wave of more than 600 migrants from Belarus on Friday after they gave up, at least for now, on a disastrous attempt to try to reach the European Union via its eastern borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Texas Abortion Law Complicates Care for Risky Pregnancies
description: Doctors in Texas say they cannot head off life-threatening medical crises in pregnant women if abortions cannot be offered or even discussed.
content: A few weeks after Texas adopted the most restrictive abortion law in the nation, Dr. Andrea Palmer delivered terrible news to a Fort Worth patient who was midway through her pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Their First Date Was 14 Years in the Making
description: Adam Dalva fell for Alana Salguero when they met at Swarthmore College in 2004. It took more than a decade for her feelings to be reciprocal.
content: Adam Dalva said he fell in love with Alana Salguero the first day he met her during freshman year at Swarthmore College in 2004. He would later write his wedding vows the night after their first date.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Undeterred by Channel’s Perils, Migrants Still Plan to Cross
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 26, 2021.
content: “I don’t believe that I’ll die. I believe I’ll get to England.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy, Raphael Minder and Gaia Pianigiani
title: In Europe, trying to find fun and games in holiday retailing.
description: Black Friday discounts are now routine for European toy stores and other retailers, but pandemic restrictions remain a big presence in some areas.
content: Black Friday is an American import that has caught on in much of Europe, embraced by retailers and shoppers as an opening trumpet blast for the start of the holiday shopping season — even if Thanksgiving remains a distant country’s holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Europe is being tested by waves of cases that threaten its progress against the pandemic.
description: The deteriorating situation is also worrisome for the United States, as trends in new Covid cases tended to follow Europe by weeks.
content: Nearly 20 months after pandemic lockdowns first began, governments across Europe are beginning to tighten restrictions again amid the latest wave of new coronavirus cases, threatening the gains that the region has made against the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: After detecting the Omicron variant, South Africa feels ‘punished’ by global travel bans.
description: Hours after South African scientists announced the existence of a troublesome new variant, Britain banned travelers from southern Africa. The United States and other nations quickly followed suit.
content: JOHANNESBURG — As the United States and European countries close their borders over fears over the recently detected coronavirus variant, many South Africans say they feel as if they are being “punished” for alerting global health authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: France-U.K. Acrimony Impedes Progress on Channel Crossings
description: Rather than working together to curb hazardous sea crossings, leaders of the two countries almost immediately fell into a familiar pattern of squabbling.
content: LONDON — At times, the quarrels between Britain and France can seem trivial and more than a little petulant. But the latest round of recrimination, following the tragic deaths of at least 27 migrants in a flimsy inflatable boat off the French coast, puts the two countries at odds on one of the thorniest issues they face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘I Savor Everything’: A Soprano’s Star Turn at the Met Opera
description: Erin Morley, a fixture at the Met for over a decade, is now singing the title role in “Eurydice.”
content: The soprano Erin Morley is no stranger to the Metropolitan Opera, where she has been a fixture for over a decade. But until now she has never been the face of the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Olympic Official Who Delivered Rio Games Sentenced to 30 Years for Bribery
description: Carlos Arthur Nuzman was found guilty after a trial that featured claims of rigged votes, gold bars and at least $2 million in payoffs to top sports officials.
content: The man who brought the Olympics to South America for the first time has been sentenced to more than 30 years in prison after a judge in Brazil ruled that Rio de Janeiro’s success at securing the 2016 Summer Games was built on a bribery scheme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A concerning new variant.
content: A new variant of the coronavirus, whose mutations show evidence of a “big jump in evolution,” is driving an increase in new Covid-19 infections in South Africa, health officials said yesterday. Scientists have so far detected 22 cases of the B1.1.529 variant in Gauteng Province, the country’s economic hub.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: U.S. officials are consulting with South African scientists on the variant.
description: Health officials in the United States were consulting with South African scientists Friday morning, according to a person familiar with the calls, but it was unclear whether the Biden administration would impose travel restrictions.
content: Health officials in the United States were consulting with South African scientists Friday morning, according to a person familiar with the calls, but it was unclear whether the Biden administration would impose travel restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: It’s Beginning to Look a Lot Like Hanukkah
description: What’s that reindeer doing with menorah antlers? Retailers want inclusive holiday merchandise, but hit a few snags.
content: A select group of holiday shoppers on TikTok have some questions for big-box retailers this winter, most notably: Do you know what “oy” means, and are you sure you want to wish it on the world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: ‘Ed the Trucker’: The Trump Republican Who’s Riding High in New Jersey
description: “If anything, my election showed nobody’s untouchable,” said Edward Durr Jr., who pulled off a stunning victory to win a New Jersey State Senate seat.
content: Edward Durr Jr., a Republican who this month toppled New Jersey’s second most powerful lawmaker, had three children under 13 when a mortgage company began foreclosure proceedings on his 1,200-square-foot, one-story home in South Jersey in 1997.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 26, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 26, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: What we know about the Omicron variant.
description: Scientists don’t know how effective vaccines will be against the new variant flagged by a team in South Africa, which displays mutations that might resist neutralization.
content: Scientists are still unclear on how effective vaccines will be against the new variant flagged by a team in South Africa, which displays mutations that might resist neutralization. Only several dozen cases have been fully identified so far in South Africa, Botswana, Hong Kong, Belgium and Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cybèle C. Greenberg
title: The Military’s Broken Culture Around Sexual Violence and Suicide
description: The Pentagon isn’t doing what is necessary to protect and care for service members facing trauma.
content: Anne Vassas loved being a Marine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Their Holiday Parties Are Just Getting Restarted
description: A pair of caterers gear up for year-end celebrations at companies. “I think they really want to encourage people to think that returning to the office is a celebration of sorts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Feta Pasta and Other Winners
description: Whether you need simple recipes or are in marathon cooking mode, we have options.
content: There are some people who collapse on the couch after Thanksgiving and don’t get up for hours, or even days. And then there are the people who treat the whole holiday weekend as a cooking and baking marathon, using up leftovers and pivoting right into cookie baking. (Speaking of: Sign up for Your Daily Cookie, our new pop-up baking newsletter, to get a new cookie recipe every day in December until Christmas.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly, David D. Kirkpatrick and Alan Rappeport
title: Seeking Backers for New Fund, Jared Kushner Turns to Middle East
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law is trying to raise capital for his investment firm and is turning to a region that he dealt with extensively while in the White House.
content: As a White House adviser in the Trump administration, Jared Kushner took a special interest in the petroleum-rich monarchies of the Persian Gulf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Italy and Portugal Could Meet for a 2022 World Cup Spot. Only One Can Go.
description: The draw for Europe’s final three qualifying places ensured that either Italy, the European champion, or Portugal, with Cristiano Ronaldo, would miss the finals in Qatar.
content: Italy and Portugal were drawn into the same World Cup qualifying bracket on Friday, ensuring that either the reigning European champion (Italy) or one of soccer’s biggest stars (Portugal’s Cristiano Ronaldo) will be absent from next year’s tournament in Qatar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Spontaneous Sedona Elopement
description: Holly Lorka and Melissa Shields decided to scrap their plans for a wedding ceremony in Austin and get married amid Arizona’s red rocks instead.
content: It didn’t take long for Melissa Shields to envision a future with Holly Lorka after they met in July 2019. When Ms. Shields got home that night, she had what she calls “clicks,” or pictures in her head of all the things the two might do together, like get married, have children and even be on a reality TV show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: How Black Friday got its name.
description: Historians say the Philadelphia police took to calling the day before the annual Army-Navy football game Black Friday because officers had to work long hours and deal with bad traffic, bad weather and other miseries.
content: The term “Black Friday” has for years been synonymous with mayhem at stores, and its origin story has roots in turbulence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: How Much Does Your Team’s Manager Matter?
description: One set of researchers estimated a manager is responsible for only 8 percent of a team’s results. But 8 percent, when you think about it, is a lot.
content: That first day, for an incoming manager at a new club, must be overwhelming. There is an entire squad of players to meet, to get to know, to win over. There is a staff, nervous of your intentions and fearful of what the future may hold, to convince and, hopefully, to command.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: New Virus Variant Stokes Concern but Vaccines Still Likely to Work
description: The Omicron variant carries worrisome mutations that may let it evade antibodies, scientists said. But it will take more research to know how it fares against vaccinated people.
content: Scientific experts at the World Health Organization warned on Friday that a new coronavirus variant discovered in southern Africa was a “variant of concern,” the most serious category the agency uses for such tracking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: The Hilarious, Heartbreaking Life and Music of Malcolm Arnold
description: He was one of the most popular British composers of his time, but there are few celebrations of Arnold’s centenary this year.
content: Five years ago, an advertisement was placed on eBay by a small auction business in Northwest London called FlogIt4U. The listing was rather more highbrow than FlogIt4U’s usual fare; it was a handwritten score, still wrapped in its original tissue paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Slain Woman Had Begged Apartment Complex to Change Locks, Lawsuit Claims
description: A New Jersey mother had been granted a temporary restraining order against her husband before he killed her and their two children, according to a suit filed by the woman’s family.
content: Fearful that her husband would come into their apartment and hurt their children, Ruth Esther Reyes de Severino “begged” the managers of Penns Grove Gardens in Salem County, N.J., to change the door locks after she was granted a temporary restraining order against him in January 2020, according to a lawsuit filed by her family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Ali Gascoigne’s cryptic is cuddly, with some claws.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — Ali Gascoigne lives in England, where cryptic constructors are “setters” and go by aliases, or “noms de cruciverb” — in his case, Gila and Jalna. Mr. Gascoigne has also constructed a few daily grids for us, including an excellent Saturday puzzle in February that was decorated with lots of clever cryptic notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: United States will bar travelers from 8 countries in southern Africa.
description: Starting Monday, travelers from South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique and Malawi will be barred unless they are citizens or permanent residents.
content: President Biden will restrict travel from South Africa and seven other African countries to try to contain a troubling new variant of the coronavirus, senior administration officials said on Friday, though they said it would be impossible to prevent it from entering the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Weiner
title: There Is Another Democrat A.O.C. Should Be Mad At
description: The monumental scale of the Build Back Better plan raises a difficult  question: Is a fleeting and narrow majority enough for making history?
content: Progressive Democrats in the House of Representatives can be forgiven their anxiety about whether Senators Joe Manchin of West Virginia and Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona will support the more than $1.8 trillion Build Back Better plan. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, for example, rues the two senators’ outsize influence, while her colleague Rashida Tlaib of Michigan worries that Mr. Manchin and Ms. Sinema are “corporate Dems” led astray by special interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Stevens
title: Swimming Upstream in Heels and Skinny Pants
description: If I were a salmon, I would die for my child. As a human being, I wish I could have.
content: I can’t stop thinking about salmon. Recently we had salmon spawning season here in Seattle, and I was able to see it for the first time. I am not a scientist, much less a marine biologist or fish expert or even a YouTube-educated hobbyist, but here’s what I have learned: It’s beautiful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: ‘Today’s Outfit Is Confidence’: Atypical TikTok Star Enchants Mexico
description: Middle-aged and scarred, a Mexican journalist is breaking the mold of social media influencers with a message of pure positivity that resonates in dark times.
content: MEXICO CITY — At 49 years old and under five feet tall, Martha Izquierdo doesn’t exactly fit the mold of a TikTok influencer. But having survived sexual abuse, kidnapping, two bouts with cancer and two heart attacks, conquering social media was practically a cinch for this Mexican journalist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Murders ‘Doubled Overnight,’ and the Percentage Solved by the N.Y.P.D. Plunged
description: The police solved nearly 90 percent of murder cases before the pandemic, but only around 60 percent in 2020.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at the jump in murders during the pandemic and the drop in cases closed by the police. And, now that Thanksgiving is behind us, we’ll also get a peek at how Macy’s is returning to in-person visits with Santa in a reconfigured workshop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: The Holiday Shopping Season Is Here, but Is It Back?
description: Shoppers are returning to stores in much bigger numbers than last year, but the atmosphere is not quite as carefree as the prepandemic days of 2019.
content: Americans more comfortable with in-store shopping were back out in greater force on Friday, and battered retailers were more optimistic than they have been at any point since the start of the pandemic, which shuttered stores and wiped out sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan, Patricia Heal and Martin Bourne
title: The Humble Beginnings of Today’s Culinary Delicacies
description: Many of our most revered dishes were perfected by those in need, then co-opted by the affluent. Is that populism at play, or just the abuse of power?
content: IN THE NEWLY moneyed Beijing of the early 1990s, a curious type of restaurant started to appear. Limousines idled in the street while, inside, diners hunched on logs or camp-style chairs strung with rope and feasted on the likes of crackly locusts, ants boiled into soup, damp weeds and wotou (a steamed bread of coarse cornmeal) — a subsistence menu that evoked the scant rations served at rural work-unit canteens during the Cultural Revolution, less than 20 years before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Cozy Season Is Here
description: A guide to your post-Thanksgiving weekend.
content: Good morning. It’s a pleasure to greet you this Friday after Thanksgiving, at the dawn of cozy season, here in the dwindling days of the year. I usually write to Times readers via the At Home and Away newsletter, where, for months, I’ve been contemplating ways we can lead a full and cultured life during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By JoAnna Novak
title: We’re Longing for the One Thing the Metaverse Can’t Give Us
description: After I’ve struggled with anorexia and bulimia for more than 20 years, the last thing I want is technology that further estranges me from my body.
content: When Mark Zuckerberg announced the rebranding of Facebook to Meta late last month in a “founder’s letter,” I was on a video call with my writing group, discussing the tactile joys of our craft — the benefits of writing by hand, our love of beautiful Rhodia writing pads, our favorite examples of manuscript pages (mine: David Foster Wallace’s, reeking of chew). Among the three of us, we owned five typewriters and no social media accounts. There we were in the metaverse, longing for the one thing it can’t provide: the experience of touch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Covetable Timepieces That Give New Meaning to the Term ‘Winter Whites’
description: Between their sprinkling of diamonds and mother-of-pearl faces, these three watches emit a gentle glow.
content: There is something to be said for understated elegance, which with this trio of watches comes in the form of mother-of-pearl faces and diamond accents. On the dial of the Tag Heuer Carrera, the gems replace numbers to mark the time, while on Omega’s De Ville Trésor, they wrap around the bezel. The Rolex Oyster Perpetual Datejust 31 has them in both places, but there, too, the overall effect is of a classic style with just a bit of sparkle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: Getting a Moral Fix From ‘Approval Junkie’
description: The radio and television journalist Faith Salie stars in a one-woman show about the perils of striving for achievement and affirmation.
content: A loosely drawn girl eyes a gold star near the top of an illustrated tree. She climbs up to reach it but tumbles to the ground and lands on her feet. The brief animation serves to introduce “Approval Junkie,” a one-woman Audible production that opened Tuesday at the Minetta Lane Theater, neatly encapsulating the whole of its familiar, and repeated, moral fable about chasing the highs of success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Time, Money and Chicken Fat: A Guide to Inflation-Proof Gift-Giving
description: Prices are soaring for almost everything, but a few choice gifts are even cheaper than two years ago. Or show your love by going on your family’s annual “lard run.”
content: If groceries, gas or automobiles were any part of your budget this year, inflation has hit you hard. Now perhaps you want to keep the gift budget in check. Then again, maybe you haven’t seen your relatives in a long while, and you’d rather not be anything less than generous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Salmon, Loss and Motherhood
description: And: ‘When are you getting married?’
content: Rachel Stevens, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, saw firsthand how female salmon die for their children during salmon spawning season in Seattle, but she didn’t realize that it would be the first of many lessons in motherhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Bittman
title: How to Make Really Good Bread
description: Baking whole wheat bread can reacquaint us with food that truly nourishes us.
content: America is no longer a Wonder Bread nation. Gone are the days when bleached, sliced and plastic-wrapped bread from the supermarket was the default. Increasingly, Americans feast on ciabatta, tortillas and pita breads and Instagram their home-baked loaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: A Times correspondent reports from a plane held on the tarmac in Amsterdam.
description: Someday, I may appreciate the irony in this situation.
content: Someday, I may appreciate the irony in this situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: On Their Small Shoulders Rest Some Big Films
description: Five children winning acclaim for their roles in “Belfast,” “King Richard,” “C’mon C’mon” and “The Tender Bar” talk us through their starring turns.
content: Jude Hill, clad in a white button-up shirt with a cheeky grin, is just as charming in real life as he is in “Belfast,” Kenneth Branagh’s new autobiographical film about an Irish boy growing up amid the Troubles in the title city in the 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: A Mine Disaster in Russia Highlights Safety Shortfalls in Rush to Dig Coal
description: At least 46 miners were killed in an explosion at a Siberian mine. The director of the mine has been taken into police custody, along with five other administrators.
content: MOSCOW — In the days before his death in a mine explosion in Russia’s coal-rich Kuzbass region, Boris Piyalkin lamented that the safety standards in his workplace were inadequate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Hong Kong records two cases of the new variant detected in South Africa.
description: The discovery could complicate efforts to reopen the border between the territory and the Chinese mainland.
content: The Hong Kong government said on Thursday that it had detected two cases of a new variant identified in South Africa, which scientists have warned shows a “big jump in evolution” and could limit the effectiveness of vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Fresh Violence in Darfur Adds to Sudan’s Crises
description: At least 43 people have been killed in clashes in the area, the U.N. says, while the nation’s leaders are focused elsewhere, dealing with the fallout from a coup.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Dozens of people have been killed and their villages burned in inter-communal violence in Sudan’s West Darfur state, the United Nations said, worsening the state of crisis that has troubled the region for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: Brandon Kyle Goodman, a Nonbinary Voice of ‘Big Mouth’
description: The actor and writer also stars in the spinoff “Human Resources.”
content: Name: Brandon Kyle Goodman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A new variant.
content: A new variant of the coronavirus was reported in South Africa, sending stocks around the world tumbling and prompting the U.S. and other countries to reinstate travel restrictions. The W.H.O. said the new variant was “of concern” and gave it the name Omicron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: He Knows Who Won the Ballon d’Or. No, He Won’t Tell.
description: Encrypted email servers, secret meetings, strict confidentiality: How the identity of the winner of the Ballon d’Or, soccer’s biggest individual prize, is guarded like a state secret.
content: At this time of year, Pascal Ferré seems to field the same call, over and over again. They come from across the world. Sometimes, it is a team executive or a club president. Often, it is an agent, charming and inquisitive. Occasionally, it might even be one of the world’s most famous players themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: They’ll Always Have Venice (and Each Other)
description: Dr. Neal Kassell and Meredith Woo became engaged while on a flight to Venice, where he has traveled more than 50 times (several with her).
content: Dr. Neal Frederic Kassell and Meredith Jung-En Woo, best of friends for years, were ambivalent about marriage as recently as three months ago. But on Sept. 9, while sitting next to each other on an airplane in relative silence, Dr. Kassell leaned over to say something to Ms. Woo, who was reading a book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Getting It Right the Second Time Around
description: Aastha Wadhwa turned Neil Chitrao down the first time he asked her out. A few months later she realized how much she missed him.
content: Even though the first few days of college were a blur for Neil Mahesh Chitrao, one moment in particular stands out: when he met Aastha Wadhwa during the convocation ceremony for the Cornell undergraduate class of 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: After Meeting With Victim, Former Missouri Officer Is Cleared of Assault
description: The charge was dropped after the former police officer and the woman she shot outside a supermarket in Ladue, Mo., agreed to meet with a mediator over Zoom, prosecutors said.
content: Two and a half years after a police officer shot a woman she suspected of shoplifting at a Missouri supermarket, prosecutors said this week that they had dismissed a felony assault charge against the former officer after the two women agreed to meet by videoconference to resolve the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: The Wandering Creativity of Sophie Taeuber-Arp
description: The Swiss artist did it all — paintings and puppets, sculpture and tapestry — and was underestimated because of it. At MoMA she joins the major leagues.
content: There’s an object in the Museum of Modern Art’s retrospective of the Swiss polymath Sophie Taeuber-Arp that’s so covetable I wanted to squeeze it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
title: Interior Dept. Report on Drilling Is Mostly Silent on Climate Change
description: The department recommended higher fees for oil and gas leases, but there was no sign the government planned to take global warming into account when weighing new applications.
content: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department on Friday recommended that the federal government raise the fees that oil and gas companies pay to drill on public lands — the first increase in those rent and royalty rates since 1920.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: That ‘Team Beto’ Fund-Raising Email? It Might Not Be From Beto.
description: Mimicking official correspondence is an age-old marketing trick. But look-alike emails suggesting links to Beto O’Rourke’s campaign for governor show the tactic has accelerated in the digital era.
content: Kenneth Pennington, a top digital strategist for Beto O’Rourke, had a simple plan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times News Quiz, November 26, 2021
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of the film “Licorice Pizza.”
content: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of the film “Licorice Pizza.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: The Weekender
description: Why this year’s ‘Nutcracker’ will look a little different. Also in this edition: the novel that riveted France during lockdown arrives in America.
content: Why this year’s ‘Nutcracker’ will look a little different. Also in this edition: the novel that riveted France during lockdown arrives in America.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Touring Climate Threats at the Museum
description: Beneath the National Museum of American History, floodwaters are intruding into collection rooms, a consequence of a warming planet. A fix remains years away.
content: Beneath the National Museum of American History, floodwaters are intruding into collection rooms, a consequence of a warming planet. A fix remains years away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Orr, Mervyn Rothstein and Robin Stein
title: The Last Word: Stephen Sondheim
description: In a never before seen interview, Stephen Sondheim sat down with The New York Times in June 2008 to talk about his life, career and accomplishments.
content: In a never before seen interview, Stephen Sondheim sat down with The New York Times in June 2008 to talk about his life, career and accomplishments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Leftovers Are Better Than the Feast
description: Make the best possible sandwich, or a big batch of turkey bone gumbo.
content: Good morning. This is where Thanksgiving gets great: a bespoke leftovers sandwich (above) eaten in the quiet of a house that was recently crowded and noisy, maybe with a glass of whole milk or one of kombucha, depending on your point of view, or with a glass of chilled Beaujolais or icy lager, depending on the time of day. Welcome to Christmas music season!
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Their 80s, and Living It Up (or Not)
description: Two octogenarians have different reactions to an essay, “Living My Life Again.” Also:  “Illiberal democracy”; housing in the Bronx; rich vs. poor
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
